title: Police Say Sorry to Lord Speaker for Mistake
summary: The police in London, called the Metropolitan Police, made a mistake and said sorry to the Lord Speaker, Lord Forsyth. They wrongly thought he told them something about Lord Mandelson, who is a former ambassador. Lord Mandelson was arrested because someone said he might leave the country, but his lawyers say this is not true. The police also said sorry to Sir Lindsay Hoyle, who is the Speaker of the House of Commons, because they accidentally said he gave them information. Sir Lindsay said he did share information with the police because he thought it was his duty. The police are investigating Lord Mandelson for possibly sharing secret government information with a bad person. Lord Mandelson says he did nothing wrong and wants to prove it. He was taken to a police station and then let go while they look into it more.

background_read: In the UK, the police work to solve crimes and keep people safe. The House of Lords and House of Commons are parts of the government that make laws. Lords are important people who help run the country. Sometimes, police make mistakes and need to apologize. Investigations happen when police look into possible wrongdoings to find out what really happened.
Article_Structure: WHO: The Metropolitan Police, Lord Forsyth (Lord Speaker), Lord Mandelson (former ambassador), Sir Lindsay Hoyle (Commons Speaker)
WHAT: Police apologized for wrongly saying Lord Forsyth gave information about Lord Mandelson's arrest; Lord Mandelson was arrested and is under investigation
WHERE: London, UK, including Wandsworth police station
WHY: To correct a mistake and explain an investigation into possible sharing of secret information
